replies.body:
The way the policy is worded, what you said earlier is incorrect. The second part, it appears, is conditional to the first — anyone who has spent at least three months on the staff team is eligible for the rank, but it is still subject to the administrators' decision whether or not the person should actually be awarded the rank. This means that someone can be a staff member for a year and still not get the rank because they are deemed unfit.

At the same time, this means that a staff member who has spent less than three months is ineligible, regardless of how the administrators feel. By giving the rank to a player who, apparently, is ineligible for it in the first place, one would basically be infringing staff policies.

I don't think it matters whether or not the rank has permissions. If there are set requirements for someone needed to have in order to acquire the 'Retired' rank, it shall be determined by those set requirements. From what I see, there is a misunderstanding of what the requirements are. There should be set requirements needed in order to acquire a 'Retired' rank, and nothing should be added unless it's official, so in the future there would be little to no confusion, or nothing dramatic like
this. Essentially what I'm saying is, have official requirements that each staff member is aware of, and make no other changes to it especially if it's not official like what I assume happened in this case, so that this whole issue wouldn't come up again.

replies.body:
A majority of the speculation here is over possible bias, not just the main purpose of this thread (Sho receiving a 'Retired' tag despite the guidelines for it saying specifically that it was for moderators whom served the server with their position 3+ months.)

In all honesty, it's now becoming a bit of a flame war to find excuses to blame the staff team for bias, even if it's not mentioned directly in the statements brought up. It's the same thing over and over, guys. The staff team do their best to ensure fun gameplay for all users by taking time out of our lives to do so. We may have a few hiccups here and there, but that doesn't mean the community of which we serve should start creating huge issues over it. We take all these occasional problems into account, even if it may not seem like it in the perspectives of others , but it's rather difficult to deal with them thoroughly with others complaining about it repetetively and losing faith in the team quite quickly.

Keep in mind that I'm not saying the staff team is perfect. I'm just pointing out some things people may not realise regarding certain topics.

I also apologise if any statements in this post are considered as rude or offensive, as this serves a different purpose other than hurting the feelings of others.

replies.body:
"The staff are biased"
You know what? GET OVER IT
Because no matter where you go, there will be bias, and you can't fix that! We are arguing over a part of a $20 dollar video game that has limitless amounts of possibilities, if you can't stand the bias, go to another server, oh wait, there's bias there too, because you know what, staff members make friends, and then they will let their friends slip, because they don't want to lose that friend, if you can't stand it that much, I suggest single player, or do something like connect with friends in survival or creative or you can download adventure maps that people have made, there's so much that you can do, so why make such a fuss, there are positives and negatives for every choice, the negatives for servers is that you have to embrace the fact that the staff are imperfect.  The staff aren't professionals, they never will be, sure they could be better, but we all can be better.  If all you ever do is complain about the server, Stop. Playing. The. Server. And. Find. Another. One

I'm not trying to tell you leave avicus, but if all you do is whine and never do anything about it, you must not care about the server very much
